Astigmatism can be corrected with a special IOL, the cost of which is not covered by insurances. This lens is called a toric IOL. They have a wide range of astigmatism focusing errors built into them. This lens can be ordered such that it corrects the astigmatism while preserving the near vision you seem to value so much. You and your ophthalmologist can select the IOL that best meets your lifestyle and visual needs during an in-person consultation.

metadata.question: Is anesthesia used for combined cataract and glaucoma surgery?

links.text: If inserting a glaucoma stent at the same time

text: is done these days with some combination of topical anesthesia (numbing eye drops or gel) and intravenous sedation. , some ophthalmologists may also perform an injection around the eye that helps with numbing and temporarily prevents eye movement, however this is up to the individual surgeon.

metadata.question: Is cataract surgery possible if taking finasteride?

text: Finasteride should not interfere with your surgery.

metadata.question: Is cataract surgery recommended on a patient with high IOP due to glaucoma ?

text: As a general rule, we try to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) before cataract surgery with medication and laser surgery. If we are unable to control eye pressure, a patient is better served with either a standalone glaucoma surgery or a combined cataract and glaucoma surgery . While it is true that cataract surgery can modestly lower pressure in some patients, uncontrolled IOP requires a more targeted glaucoma procedure than cataract surgery alone.

metadata.question: Is current measurement technology more predictable than using pre- and post- LASIK records for selecting an IOL for cataract surgery ?

text: Yes, current formulas paired with measurement technology give more accurate IOL powers than pre- and post-LASIK information.

metadata.question: My right eye has always had the stronger prescription for my contact lenses . Does this indicate that my right eye is my dominant eye, and should be the one set for distance during cataract surgery ?

text: Eye dominance is measured separately from prescription. Just the fact that one eye has a stronger prescription does not make it the dominant eye. Most people have one eye that they use for distance activities (like sighting a gun or looking through a telescope). This is usually the "dominant eye." Even when both eyes are open, the brain pays more attention what the dominant eye is seeing. With contact lenses or with intraocular lenses (after cataract surgery) , some patients choose to have monovision where one eye is set to focus for distance and the other eye is set for reading or computer work. The dominant eye is typically set for distance vision.

metadata.question: Is hair loss a side effect of Avastin injections in the eye ? I noticed large amount of hair loss after four treatments.

text: There is no evidence that hair loss is a side effect of Avastin injections.

metadata.question: Is it best to select a cataract surgeon who also does LASIK when looking for someone to do post-LASIK cataract surgery?

text: When selecting a cataract surgeon, I recommend relying on the recommendations of others-family, friends, etc. It is best to pick the best cataract surgeon as those that do not do LASIK usually have arrangements with other surgeons to perform laser vision correction if necessary. What's most important is that you select a surgeon who is comfortable with post-LASIK cataract surgery . If you choose a surgeon who does both, that definitely works. But is not a requirement for good surgical results.

metadata.question: Is it normal to have a lower reading glasses prescription after cataract surgery ? My eyes are completely healed from the surgery.

text: The reading glasses prescription depends on the power of the lens implant (intraocular lens or IOL) that was placed inside your eye. Your reading glass power is inconsequential. What's more important is that your reading vision is satisfactory while wearing the glasses.

metadata.question: Is it possible that the IOL implant after cataract surgery would prohibit use of progressive eyeglasses ("no-line" glasses that correct vision at more than one distance)?

text: My general answer is that it would be quite unusual. I would tend not to use the word prohibit, and instead say that there could be something about the way the optics of the eye and the lens interact to make the progressive eyeglasses ineffective or less comfortable. Unfortunately, it is difficult to answer your question without knowing more about the implanted lens and your refractive outcome.

metadata.question: Is it possible to get posterior capsular opacification without having cataract surgery?

text: No, this only develops after cataract surgery . One can develop posterior subcapsular cataract that clouds the center part of the lens in front of the posterior capsule of the lens . This is more common in young people with cataract, or cataract resulting from chronic steroid use, or from trauma to the eye.

metadata.question: Is it possible to have successful cataract surgery on patients who have had radial keratotomy (prior to LASIK being an option)?

text: People who have had radial keratotomy (or RK, a refractive surgery similar to LASIK that is no longer done) can have very successful results after cataract surgery. However, radial keratotomy reshapes the cornea in ways that can continue to change over many years, and even from day to day, causing fluctuation of vision. This can make it more difficult to target a precise glasses prescription after surgery, and your glasses prescription may continue to change over time. Fortunately, most RK patients can achieve good vision with glasses or contact lenses after cataract surgery.

metadata.question: Is it possible to have one type of cataract in one eye and another in the fellow eye?

text: Yes it's possible and not uncommon. Cataracts differ in appearance and where they form on the eye's lens . People can have a combination of cataract types while others will only have one.

metadata.question: Is it safe to have cataract surgery after getting permanent makeup?

text: Permanent eye makeup will have no bearing on future cataract surgery .

metadata.question: Is it safe to have cataract surgery after having laser and freezing treatment on my retina?

text: Cataract surgery is a relatively safe operation with an extremely low complication rate. There are some ocular, medical and surgical conditions that can add to this very low risk. Previous retinal surgery might indicate an underlying weakness in the retina -such as high nearsightedness and previous eye injury -that could add to the risk of cataract surgery. However, areas of the retina that have been fully treated are usually the least likely areas to cause any of these complications. Prior to your cataract surgery, your ophthalmologist will fully and carefully examine your eye, including the retina, to prepare accordingly and provide you a safe operation.

metadata.question: Is it safe to have cataract surgery if I have an abscessed tooth?

text: As with any surgery, any active infection should be treated prior to cataract removal.

metadata.question: I am 59 years old and have congenital nystagmus (involuntary, rapid movement of the eyes) . Now I have developed cataract in both eyes and need surgery. How would this surgery be performed while my eyeballs are moving? My ophthalmologist surgeon thinks he can handle it and wants to do it in local anesthesia. Would it be safe? Is there a safer way?

text: I have performed cataract surgery on a number of patients with nystagmus, and I've never found it to be a particularly challenging problem. It is relatively straightforward to immobilize the eye with a second instrument while making incisions. Once the incisions are complete, having the surgical instruments in the eye dampens the nystagmus, and makes the procedure relatively routine.

metadata.question: Is it safe to have an MRI body scan if I had cataract surgery two years ago?

text: Yes, it's safe. However, any interior magnetic items (such as a pacemaker or inner ear implant) should always be discussed with your doctor before an MRI. This question was originally answered on Jul. 26, 2017.

metadata.question: Is it safe to use flaxseed eye mask for dry eye after cataract surgery?

text: I do not recommend this treatment. If you have dry eye the treatments may include various types of drops and punctual plugs . If you have eyelid inflammation such as blepharitis , eyelid scrubs and warm compresses may also help. Warm compresses can be applied in a number of ways. Microwaveable flaxseed eye mask is not going to be any better than applying a warm facecloth to the eye. That being said, check with your eye surgeon before doing anything not specifically described in your post-op instructions during the early months after cataract surgery.

metadata.question: Is it true that after cataract surgery my new eyeglasses prescription will never change?

text: Assuming healthy eyes, you may have slight changes as you age, but no large changes anymore.

metadata.question: Is it true that I should expect my vision to change after cataract surgery ? Even if I choose the standard lens?

text: In a healthy eye, the sharpness of vision is a function of several features: the front surface curvature (cornea) , the focusing power of the lens , and the length of the eyeball. When one of these is less than perfect for sharp vision, eyeglasses or contact lenses are prescribed to sharpen the vision. Cataract surgery destroys the lens of the eye and a replacement artificial lens is placed inside the eye. It almost always lasts forever. The focusing power of that artificial lens can be calculated, within a small degree of error, to be whatever you and your ophthalmologist desire the visual outcome to be. Therefore, if you want to have excellent distance vision you may make that choice. If you prefer to have excellent near vision you may choose that option. If you wish to have the same vision you currently have, you may make that choice. All of this depends on several factors, one of which is the focusing power of the fellow eye as they must be kept reasonably close to the same so as not to make an imbalance. I fear I may have oversimplified this issue for the purposes of this setting and strongly urge you to discuss your visual outcome preferences fully with your ophthalmologist.

metadata.question: For surgery fixing a posterior subcapsular cataract, does laser cataract surgery offer benefits over traditional cataract surgery?

text: Laser assisted cataract surgery and conventional cataract surgery are highly successful methods for treating, generally, all types of cataracts. Studies suggest that clinical outcomes are no different when comparing different surgical approaches. Speak with your ophthalmologist about what approach would be best for you.

metadata.question: Is midazolam a good anesthetic to use during cataract surgery?

text: The choice of anesthetic or sedative to use during cataract surgery will vary, depending on preferences of the surgeon and anesthesiologist. Of course, the medical issues of the patient and the patient preferences also are important. Midazolam is not an anesthetic but rather a benzodiazepine sedative. Personally, I think midazolam is often a good option to use for cataract surgery, but there are many options available.

metadata.question: Three years ago, at age 63, I had cataract surgery on my non-dominant right eye, with the intraocular lens set for distance vision, and incisions to address some astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) . I have been nearsighted all my life, in glasses since age 13, and have worn single-vision glasses since the right eye surgery to sharpen my right eye to 20/20 distance. My dominant left eye cataract now needs to be addressed. From what I have read about monovision, the proper set-up is that the dominant eye is set to distance. Since my non-dominant right eye has already been set to distance, is monovision a viable option for me? Also, if I were to go with monovision versus both eyes set to distance, how will my depth perception be affected, especially driving at night?

text: Monovision would not be recommended for your situation for two reasons: Near vision in the dominant eye and distance in the non-dominant eye can be visually confusing and, yes, can affect depth perception. Also, if you have never tried monovision in contact lenses when you were younger, I never recommend monovision, as most do not adapt well to it without previous experience. Nothing is wrong with setting both eyes for distance and wearing some reading glasses. Please discuss your options with your ophthalmologist.

metadata.question: Is it safe to have an MRI one week after cataract surgery?

text: There is no problem having an MRI solely due to recent or not so recent cataract surgery . So, yes, one week after cataract surgery does not make an MRI exam less safe.

metadata.question: My husband has nystagmus (involuntary movement of the eyes) and needs cataract surgery . Is a multifocal lens an option with nystagmus?

links.text: cornea (clear, front window of the eye)
retina (light sensitive tissue lining the back of the eye)

text: Multifocal lens implants are reserved for eyes with normal optical systems meaning normal muscle function, normal tear layer (area above the cornea that keeps the eye lubricated), normal cornea (clear, front window of the eye) , and normal retina (light sensitive tissue lining the back of the eye) . Nystagmus involves abnormal muscle function so a multifocal lens implant should not be used in this situation and both eyes should either be set for distance vision or near vision. Monovision (one eye set for near vision and the other for distance vision) is also not an option with nystagmus. If distance correction is decided, then glasses will be needed for near vision. Alternatively, both eyes can be set at near vision meaning glasses will need to be worn for distance.

metadata.question: Is a multifocal IOL safe/recommended for use if you have uncomplicated diabetes ?

text: Yes, as long as you have no diabetic retinopathy . Be sure to confirm with your ophthalmologist after you have had a complete dilated eye exam that the diabetes has not affected your vision.

metadata.question: My daughter, who is 6 years old, was recently diagnosed with a cataract . She had some blood work done, and her ANA test (a blood test that helps diagnose autoimmune disease) was positive. We did a second round of blood work to test for Lyme, and that is positive as well. Is this cataract directly related to the Lyme disease?

text: There is no way to give a true answer to this, as most with Lyme disease or autoimmune disease (goes with the ANA) do not necessarily develop early cataracts. However, if she has been on chronic steroid treatment, this could lead to early cataract. A pediatric ophthalmologist would be best to follow up with in regard to these issues.

metadata.question: Is pupil size a consideration when choosing a lens for cataract surgery?

text: may be a consideration when choosing before . The Light Adjustable Lens (LAL) requires at least a 7 mm dilated pupil, so the power can be adjusted after surgical healing. Pupil size can also affect the performance of multifocal IOLs. A too small pupil may decrease the sharpness of near and intermediate vision, while a bigger pupil may cause problems with glare and distance vision.

metadata.question: Is pre- and post-refractive testing necessary for cataract surgery when you are using a standard Medicare-covered lens?

text: Yes, the pre-tests are to check the health of the eye as well as taking the corneal measurements, which are used to calculate the lens implant power. The testing after surgery is for deciding on what glasses , if any, are needed after surgery.

metadata.question: My brother had cataract surgery . Immediately following surgery his vision improved markedly, then got increasingly worse. The doctor said he has a sensitivity to the preservatives in prednisolone that is causing worsening vision, eye pain, headaches, but he needs the prednisolone. My brother can't take the side effects anymore and wants to quit the prednisolone. Is there another steroid he can take that doesn't have preservatives?

text: There is no commercially available non-preserved steroid, however it is possible that a compounding pharmacy can make one for you. However, there are several different types of commercially available steroids and if your brother absolutely requires a steroid for inflammation after cataract surgery perhaps your ophthalmologist can try a different one.

metadata.question: Is there a cure for mydriasis (dilated pupils )? I have lived most of my life with pupils that are abnormally huge and take up most of my iris . In normal lighting, they're huge, but outside, they're able to respond to light accordingly. This condition is very embarrassing because it leads people to ask the question, "Are you on drugs?"

text: You are lucky that your pupils are not paralyzed in the open position. Therefore, they apparently are able to constrict (narrow or become smaller) with light input. There is a very effective drug which can constrict pupils which you might consider. This drug is an ancient one in ophthalmology called Pilocarpine. It is used to treat the elevated pressure of glaucoma , but in young persons also affects focusing and so it has fallen out of favor. However, in low doses, at about the level of 1/2 to 1/4 percent, it can bring down the pupils with little effect on the focusing. Two problems: It is not a cure and will need to be applied daily and secondly pharmacies do not regularly stock this, and when available, is usually in the 2% concentrations so you would need a compounding pharmacy to prepare the more diluted (less powerful) solution. A few bottles prepared this way might help you out if you use it only prior to potentially embarrassing social situations. It is also exceptionally stable so if you get several bottles prepared this way, they can be stored in the refrigerator or even in the freezer and be kept for many years.

metadata.question: I had a light adjustable lens (LAL) implanted in one eye 4 months ago. After YAG treatment a month later, I developed prominent starbursts around lights and it has been persistent ever since. Now, with the lens power locked in, I have good vision. But is there treatment available for the starbursts?

text: I would have your ophthalmologists take a thorough look during a dilated eye exam . Sometimes, simply making the YAG laser opening larger can improve these symptoms.

metadata.question: Is the refraction vision test required after cataract surgery ?

text: It is not required but is usually performed in the first two to three weeks after surgery. It is not covered by insurance, so if the vision is close to 20/20, it does not have to be performed.

metadata.question: Is vitrectomy surgery riskier after having cataract surgery?

links.text: complete eye exam by your ophthalmologist

text: risks typically include infection, and/or , bleeding, decreased vision, and needing more or additional surgery. typically does not increase the risks of vitrectomy surgery. It is important to have a to evaluate the health of your eyes and to discuss the risks and benefits of vitrectomy surgery.

metadata.question: Is YAG capsulotomy safe with hypermobile EDS (or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a disease that affects connective tissue)?

text: If the lens implant (intraocular lens) is stable there is no reason a YAG capsulotomy-a laser treatment needed for some people after cataract surgery-cannot be done.

metadata.question: Is laser-assisted cataract surgery a risk for macular swelling with a macular pucker?

text: The laser can be used to soften the cataract before it is removed, decreasing the amount of energy required to break up and remove the cataract. The laser allows for more precise placement of the incisions made in the cornea and lens , which can be helpful with more advanced implant lenses (toric or multifocal IOLs) . Both laser-assisted and standard cataract surgery have a low risk of cystoid macular edema (swelling) . Your macular pucker (also called epiretinal membrane) may increase the risk of this complication with either procedure. Your surgeon knows your specific situation and can better explain your risk of this problem.

metadata.question: within the last year. Is it possible to have LASIK surgery now to reduce my dependence on glasses? I have astigmatism in both eyes.

text: Depending on the type and amount of correction and the health of your corneas, LASIK is certainly a possibility . Schedule a discussion with your surgeon who can identify the best strategy to meet your visual goals given your eye health.

metadata.question: Should you have LASIK if you have cataracts ?

text: LASIK surgery is not advised if cataracts are affecting your vision. Moreover, having any amount of cataract means that the good vision gained from LASIK may be short lived as the cataract will continue to grow and eventually change your vision. It is actually common for LASIK to be done after cataract surgery to fine-tune the patient's vision.

metadata.question: In 2018 I developed a lazy eye turning in. I just had cataract and astigmatism surgery. My eye is now normal and straight. What happened? I don't need prism or glasses to see anymore.

links.text: But if a cataract reduces vision significantly, surgery to remove it

text: It's hard to know for sure what lead to this improvement. But if a cataract reduces vision significantly, surgery to remove it can also improve the strabismus as it is easier for the brain to hold the images from each eye together.

metadata.question: Is the light-adjustable lens an option if I had surgery for macular pucker 5 years ago?

text: Yes, it's actually a good idea. Because after cataract surgery , your surgeon adjusts the power of the light-adjustable lens to achieve the best possible vision.

metadata.question: I had cataract surgery with a monofocal lens implant placed in my left eye three weeks ago. Since then I have been disoriented and nauseous. My right eye is almost 20/20 and I have not done surgery in that eye yet. I had to get stronger reading glasses after the surgery. What is making me so nauseous?

text: The difference in correction from the distance eye to the now near eye may be a bit much for you to handle - about two diopters is all that most can tolerate. See where you are with your ophthalmologist and if there is too much difference, consider LASIK to bring the eyes a bit closer together (less nearsighted in the monofocal IOL near eye). This question was originally answered on Mar. 10, 2014.

metadata.question: If I have a monofocal IOL set for distance, will my near vision be worse than it was before cataract surgery?

links.text: a more advanced IOL that focuses at both near and far distances

text: Yes. The only reason you have good near vision in that eye now is you have some nearsightedness (myopia) . This will be gone after your cataract surgery , and you will require readers. An alternative-if you are willing to pay out-of-pocket-is to get a more advanced IOL that focuses at both near and far distances .

metadata.question: I had a cataract removed from my right eye , but I don't want to use the same surgeon for the other eye. Can I go to a different surgeon, and if so, which records do I need to provide?

links.text: In most cases, where the surgery on the first eye was standard or uncomplicated
the power and model of the intraocular lens (IOL) used in the right eye

text: In most cases, where the surgery on the first eye was standard or uncomplicated , the new surgeon would not need much from the old record. It would be ideal to have the power and model of the intraocular lens (IOL) used in the right eye . If you experienced any complicating issues-either during the surgery or afterwards-- the new surgeon may want to know the details, and in that case, the entire record would be helpful. Your new surgeon can decide what they might need from you-aside from the IOL and its power--after learning the details of your first procedure.

metadata.question: I just developed a PVD and see floaters and flashes . How long should I wait to have cataract surgery with less chance of complications?

text: After an uncomplicated posterior vitreous detachment (PVD), you can have cataract surgery as soon as your schedule allows without an increase in risk. However, please consult your cataract surgeon to see if they have any specific rules.

metadata.question: Can a retina examination be done if there is a cataract?

links.text: A cataract, or cloudy lens, usually obstructs the patient’s vision

text: A cataract, or cloudy lens, usually obstructs the patient's vision , but as it sits in front of the retina , it can also obstruct your ophthalmologist's view during a retinal exam. The more advanced the cataract is, the more limited the retinal examination will be and the less your ophthalmologist can see during a regular eye exam. There are other imaging tools to perform a retinal exam on a patient with a cataract, such as OCT (optical coherence tomography) imaging and ocular ultrasound. They may or may not be necessary depending on how advanced the cataract is, and your ophthalmologist will let you know following your dilated eye exam .

metadata.question: Can multifocal IOLs be used with strabismus?

text: I would say it is best to avoid a multifocal IOL (intraocular lens) with strabismus (misaligned or crossed eyes) . This could be a problem because sometimes correcting the patient's vision with an IOL can make the patient see double if their eyes are still misaligned after cataract surgery. If you end up needing strabismus surgery, it could make that procedure more complicated as well. Please consult with both your cataract surgeon and your strabismus specialist so they can help you choose the IOL that is right for your specific situation.

metadata.question: I have severe vertigo and vestibular disorder and will need cataract surgery in the future. With the knowledge that only a small change to my eyeglass prescription worsens my vertigo, should I expect the IOL to do the same?

text: I think cataract surgery should not affect your vertigo. I would be very careful to try to get the best uncorrected vision as possible with your intraocular lens (IOL) after surgery so you can avoid using glasses for distance vision. A detailed discussion with your surgeon should clarify expectations about your visual goals.

metadata.question: As a patient considering ORA (Optiwave Refractive Analysis) during cataract surgery , can I obtain a copy of the monitor's biometry data?

text: There is no printout that I know of, although you may want to confirm this with your surgeon. The information from ORA is simply used to confirm the readings that were taken in the office.

metadata.question: I'm considering IOL surgery and I have a lazy eye . The glasses and contact lenses I wear seem to straighten it to a degree that is hardly noticeable. Would IOLs also have this compensating effect? I'm aware it will never be perfect, but I don't want it worse than it is now.

text: The IOL should provide the same optical benefit as your glasses or contact lenses . The only change will be the loss of any "camouflage" effect the frame or lens may provide by partially hiding the appearance of the turned eye.

metadata.question: Is it OK if I put nexanac drops in the wrong eye?

links.text: I’m assuming you were prescribed these drops to reduce pain and inflammation

text: I'm assuming you were prescribed these drops to reduce pain and inflammation after cataract surgery . If you used these drops accidentally in the eye it was not prescribed for, it would be extremely unlikely that any problem would occur. However, it's always best to discuss any issues involving your medication with your prescribing physician or your pharmacist.

metadata.question: I am 73 and have a cataract in my left eye. I had 20/20 vision in both eyes until the cataract began to affect vision in my left eye. When I was younger, I had 20/10 vision in both eyes. What IOL is best for someone who doesn't need any correction? All I read is geared to those who are nearsighted or farsighted prior to cataract surgery .

text: Any type of intraocular lens (IOL) can be considered in this situation. Most commonly a monofocal IOL would be chosen for distance vision, which would require glasses for reading and intermediate vision. An extended depth-of-focus IOL can be used to offer distance with an extension of clarity to the intermediate range and glasses for reading up close. A multifocal IOL can give you vision at all distances with the cost of some glare and halos at night in some cases. Your eye health must be very good (for example, the cornea and retina need to be normal) for this lens to work as is expected. Lastly, a light adjustable IOL may be used, and the post operative vision can be adjusted. For example, it would be possible to have one eye with better distance vision, and then have the second eye adjusted to offer better close vision, as long as it is tolerated.

metadata.question: Do premium IOLs require laser-assisted surgery while traditional surgery with a blade is only for implanting basic monofocal IOLs?

text: Having femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) may be beneficial in some cases. However, FLACS not required in order to use premium or advanced technology intraocular lenses. All of these lenses may be used whether or not the surgery is standard or laser assisted.

metadata.question: Can I use Flomax after cataract surgery ?

links.text: iris's (the colored part of your eye) muscles

text: Yes and it will not interfere with your healing. You may be thinking how Flomax and similar medications (known as BPH medication or alpha-blockers) can affect the iris's (the colored part of your eye) muscles during the surgery. Before surgery, tell your ophthalmologist that you take these medications, so they can prepare for any side effects that may arise from them. After the surgery, there is no issue taking these drugs as it relates to your operated eye(s).

metadata.question: My breast cancer metastasized to the tissue of my orbits in both eyes and I'm noticing blurry vision, watering and burning sensation. Will radiation affect my IOLs?

text: I'm sorry you're dealing with these problems. You can be rest assured that there is no evidence radiation treatment will affect your intraocular lenses .

metadata.question: Can one have a cataract removed without correcting vision? I am nearsighted with astigmatism but do a lot of close-up work. I don't mind wearing glasses and like being able to take off my glasses to see very up close and want to avoid the potential side effects of IOLs.

text: An important part of the discussion that should take place with your ophthalmologist before cataract surgery is how you would like to have your vision corrected. This includes the different intraocular lenses (or IOLs) that may be available to you, as well as the refractive target, which in your case is to remain nearsighted . A helpful way to think about this is where you would like your vision to have the best focus and how clear you would like it to be without glasses. An experienced ophthalmologist should be able to make recommendations with your preferences in mind.

metadata.question: I had cataract surgery with one eye corrected for distance and the other for near vision. After many years my distance is not so good. Can I get monovision glasses to correct this?

links.text: If you would like monovision without glasses

text: This really depends on your correction, but if you are going to wear glasses in any way to correct your vision, I would recommend progressive lenses that will correct both eyes for all distances. If you would like monovision without glasses , contact lenses are the preferred option.

metadata.question: Is there such a thing as having cataract surgery too early in the natural history of the disease process? I may live another 30 years after cataract surgery and wonder what sort of ophthalmic advancements may occur after surgery at 65.

links.text: However, if your cataract interferes with any of your daily activities

text: Technology is always evolving. However, if your cataract interferes with any of your daily activities , then I would recommend surgery with the current available technology. Today's technology delivers excellent results that will endure. If clearer vision can improve your quality of life now, why wait another 10 years or more?

metadata.question: I just had cataract surgery on my left (dominant) eye with a lens for distant vision . I'm wearing my old glasses (-4.00 in each lens) and I can see distance objects very well, even though the left eye has a distance lens implanted. Why is that? I thought the left eye wouldn't be able to function with the glasses.

links.text: setting the right eye for near vision (called monovision)

text: You might be suppressing the distance vision in your operated eye while wearing your glasses and using your unoperated right eye for distance. If your distance vision is fine without glasses, you might consider setting the right eye for near vision (called monovision) if you have cataract surgery in this eye in the future. However, if your distance vision without glasses is not great, then the right eye should be set for distance vision as well, leaving you more dependent on reading glasses for near vision with both eyes. It is somewhat unusual (although not impossible) to suppress the dominant eye when viewing distance, and this suggests that perhaps your right eye is actually dominant, or that you don't have a heavily weighted dominant eye.

metadata.question: Within a week of cataract surgery , my distance vision is blurrier with more sunlight. Could I have a PCO already?

links.text: a YAG capsulotomy can fix the problem at about three months after your surgery

text: Yes, you may have early PCO or posterior capsule opacification (when the capsule holding your eye's lens becomes cloudy after cataract surgery). Sometimes early deposits on the posterior capsule resolve on their own. If this is the cause and does not resolve itself, a YAG capsulotomy can fix the problem at about three months after your surgery .

metadata.question:
I had a cataract removed as an infant , which was replaced with a monofocal IOL . At 23, that eye remains slightly amblyopic .
If adults can improve their amblyopia after damaging their good eye, can this help me? And what would be the consequences of using an intentionally wrong prescription (contacts or glasses) to cloud the good eye? Would there potentially be any negative consequences of this?

text: It is so nice to hear of your good visual outcome from cataract surgery in infancy. At 23 years of age it would be unusual for any treatment to improve the vision further. Vision researchers continue to work on developing ways to reopen vision development. On the other part of your question I do not believe there would be any harm to your good eye from some blur or patching but there is little good evidence that this would help your amblyopic eye (or an eye that failed to develop normal vision during childhood). It is true that if a patient with an amblyopic eye has severe or total vision loss in their "good" eye, then vision in the amblyopic eye may improve somewhat, but this rarely would result in "normal" vision.

metadata.question: Is it safe to have YAG while you have PVD? It's been 5 months since the PVD started.

links.text: The YAG laser used during a posterior capsulotomy poses
carry a low but real risk of retinal tear

text: The YAG laser used during a posterior capsulotomy poses no risk to the vitreous inside the eye or its age-related detachment process if already underway. However, YAG capsulotomy does carry a low but real risk of retinal tear (average risk is less than 1%) and this risk is greatest if the PVD (posterior vitreous detachment) is in process or has recently occurred. Based on recent research it is typically recommended that you wait at least 6 months following a complete PVD before proceeding with YAG capsulotomy to decrease the risk of retinal tear and detachment . There may be special circumstances affecting the timing of your procedure so please discuss this question with your eye surgeon.

metadata.question: One month after cataract surgery , why do I feel a scratchy sensation in my eyelid?

links.text: Your eye might feel a bit dry

text: It is not uncommon to feel a bit of scratchiness after cataract surgery. Your eye might feel a bit dry , and you may have sensitivity to the post-surgical drops or the sutures if they were used to seal the incision. Please discuss this and any other symptoms with your surgeon.

metadata.question: How soon after cataract surgery can I try to get pregnant?

text: We have no evidence that drops that are used after cataract surgery have any effect on the fetus. However out of abundance of caution, you may want to wait until surgery is completed on the second eye and you've stopped taking any post-operative medication. This is usually 5 weeks after cataract surgery.

metadata.question: Are there accommodations for cataract surgery patients with mobility problems? My mother is overweight and we're told she needs to be removed from her wheelchair multiple times for testing. Are there workarounds to meet these testing requirements that allow her to stay in her chair?

text: While it is easiest if someone is able to transfer to an exam chair or surgical stretcher, some offices and surgery centers/hospitals are able to accommodate wheelchair-bound individuals who are unable to transfer. You should discuss your concerns with your mother's ophthalmologist and/or office manager, as they may have such "workarounds." That said, sometimes referral to a different ophthalmologist is necessary and in the patient's best interest.

metadata.question: With mini-monovision after cataract surgery , I use my non-dominant left eye for distance. I wear driving glasses, which provide crisp distance vision and I am also able to see the dashboard clearly. I noticed, however, when I close my right eye, I cannot see clearly with my left. It is almost as if the monovision has been reversed. Is this a concern?

text: With monovision (or blended vision) , a person's "dominant" eye is typically corrected to see better at a distance, while their "non-dominant" eye is corrected to see better up close. Glasses for driving usually correct both eyes to see better at a distance. If you are having trouble seeing clearly out of your left eye while wearing glasses, then have them checked by the optician who sold them to you. If the optician confirms the glasses were made correctly, then follow up with the eye care provider who wrote the glasses prescription to have this rechecked.

metadata.question: As I am allergic to NSAIDs, are there eye drops with acetaminophen I can use after cataract surgery?

links.text: Please note that topical NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) drops

text: There is no drop that contains acetaminophen. Please note that topical NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) drops are not an absolute requirement for safe cataract surgery . If you are truly allergic to NSAIDs then talk to your surgeon about not using them topically. They will most likely say that that is fine.

metadata.question: Does a high risk of IOL dislocation in nearsighted eyes preclude laser capsulotomy treatment of PCO?

text: It does not. If the intraocular lens (IOL) is currently stable and in place and there is clinically significant posterior capsule opacification (PCO) then a posterior capsulotomy is indicated and can and should be done.

metadata.question: Should an oculoplastic specialist examine my ptosis before cataract surgery ?

text: It is ideal, but not mandatory, for an oculoplastic surgeon to evaluate a droopy eyelid (ptosis) before cataract surgery. It's important to understand the cause of the ptosis, as there can be refractive changes from severe ptosis that may impact IOL (intraocular lens) selection. The ptosis may worsen after cataract surgery. Ultimately, it is up to the patient and the discretion of the cataract surgeon to determine timing of referral to an oculoplastic surgeon.

metadata.question: Should an oil bubble to hold a detached retina in place be used if there is an artificial lens in that same eye?

text: Yes, having an artificial intraocular lens (IOL) does not prevent the use of silicone oil in the eye to help repair a retinal detachment . Silicone oil is often used for retinal detachment repair in eyes with IOLs.

metadata.question: What should a person's blood pressure be before cataract surgery and what is considered too high?

text: In general, since cataract surgery is a voluntary procedure, most surgeons would choose not to operate if there are medical problems that are found to be uncontrolled. Most surgeons would hold off on surgery if the diastolic blood pressure is above 100 or systolic blood pressure is above 160 to 180 or so. The other factor to consider is the patient's baseline blood pressure. If the blood pressure is significantly higher than baseline then one must consider whether the patient's blood pressure is safely under control. Sometimes anticipation of surgery can cause a spike in blood pressure on arrival to the surgery center, which will then decrease after relaxing for a while. This question was originally answered on Jun. 2, 2015.

metadata.question: After having an IOL implanted in my "bad" eye , the "good" eye now seems more cloudy, like the old eye used to. Is that because the eye that had cataract surgery is now highlighting the fellow eye's previously unnoticed weakness?

links.text: Yes, most likely both eyes had cataracts

text: Yes, most likely both eyes had cataracts and now that the first eye has been corrected, it lets you know that the "better" eye actually had issues as well. Plan to get the other eye done and you will be more in balance and happier with your vision.

metadata.question: I have pathological myopia . I am wondering if it would be preferable to maximize near distance instead of far distance in lens choice , as my eye will continue to elongate after cataract surgery.

text: It is doubtful that your eye will continue to elongate but you may experience some atrophy in the pigment in the central part of the retina . It is very important that you consult with a retina specialist yearly. Because it is the lens that will make you more myopic as you get older, and it is this lens that will be removed by cataract surgery , you are free to pick whatever distance you wish for correction.

metadata.question: I had secondary cataract soon after cataract surgery on one eye and did YAG. Now that I've done the other eye, am I more likely to get secondary cataract again?

links.text: the tissue (lens capsule) that once held your eye’s natural lens
YAG laser treatment (or posterior capsulotomy) is very safe and effective

text: Secondary cataract (also known as posterior capsule opacification) is when the tissue (lens capsule) that once held your eye's natural lens becomes cloudy after cataract surgery . It is common and can take months or years to develop. In my experience what happens in one eye is similar to what happens in the other. But that is not always the case. The type of cataract, specifics about the particular surgery, and the post-operative course also play an important role and this may differ between the two eyes. Nonetheless, I wouldn't be overly concerned because modern YAG laser treatment (or posterior capsulotomy) is very safe and effective .

metadata.question: I accidentally rubbed my eye two weeks after my cataract surgery . Do you think this caused any damage?

text: Rubbing your eye gently two weeks after cataract surgery is unlikely to cause harm to the eye. Vigorous rubbing, however, could cause a corneal abrasion and even damage the surgical wound. If you have any pain or change in vision, please see your surgeon right away. This question was originally answered on Feb. 21, 2014.

metadata.question: I just had cataract surgery and when I went outside at night I saw streams or long streaks of light across the outdoor lights everywhere I looked. Can it be corrected and will it go away over time?

text: Our pupils dilate in dim light, and this can cause or increase optical aberrations such as you describe, especially following cataract surgery. Still, there are potential genuine issues associated with these symptoms. You should see your ophthalmologist and have them confirm that the intraocular lens is ideally centered and your eye is in good condition. This question was originally answered on Feb. 21, 2014.

metadata.question: during the surgery a few days ago. Will it help my brain adjust to near vision by not wearing reading glasses or are there other ways to help my brain adapt to near vision better?

text: This would depend on the other eye. If your multifocal IOL was just recently inserted then you may need some time for the vision to clear at all distances. Also, if your other eye requires spectacles to read this may be a barrier to reading without glasses. Multifocal IOLs tend to work best after being inserted in both eyes. Multifocal IOLs are not guaranteed to eliminate the need for spectacles at all distances, and there may be times when glasses may help for distance, reading or in between. To your question, I do find that if the reading is good enough without using glasses, then not using them may help you acclimate to your new ability to read and allow the brain to choose the near image to focus on.

metadata.question: I had cataract surgery performed in my right eye five months ago without complications and excellent results. I can still see clearly with my left eye which has not been operated on. Should I go ahead and have cataract surgery in my left eye too even though vision in it is still good?

text: Cataract surgery is done to improve vision that interferes with quality of life issues, like working or driving. If the lens in the fellow eye is not interfering with your quality of life, but a patient wishes to have it removed, this would usually be considered an elective procedure. This means it is not covered by health insurance. Therefore, if the vision in your left eye "is still good," you may want to consider delaying surgery until your eye develops a cataract such that it interferes with your quality of life. In certain circumstances, an ophthalmologist may recommend cataract surgery when the patient does not complain of vision problems - surgery to balance the eyes may decrease the risk of falls (which can cause hip fractures) or decrease the risk of angle closure glaucoma . A discussion with your ophthalmologist after a thorough in-person exam will help you reach a decision that is best for you.

metadata.question: Should I have eyelid skin tags ("benign," or non-cancerous, small growths of the skin) removed before cataract surgery ?

text: Please ask your surgeon what her preference may be. In general. the removal of a benign skin tag is not a preoperative requirement. Unless, of course, you have a habit of rubbing your eyes in the area of the skin tags, which could cause problems after surgery.

metadata.question: I have two corneal grafts (transplants) and need cataract surgery . My surgeon would implant toric intraocular lenses (IOLs) for astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) as part of the procedure. In discussing the risks involved he says that I eventually may need new corneal transplants because of the continual changing nature of my corneas. If so, the implanted lenses would be a total mismatch for the new corneas. Is it possible to remove IOLs after a prolonged period such as 10 years? Is this ever done?

text: This is an extremely complicated and nuanced decision. If your grafts are clear and stable and the astigmatism is regular then I would consider a toric intraocular lens. If the grafts are unstable, meaning changing or beginning to fail and repeat transplants are imminent then I would not consider a toric IOL. And, yes, implants can be exchanged but the longer they have been in the more difficult that may be.

metadata.question: Should patients with pseudoexfoliation syndrome have laser cataract surgery ?

links.text: intraocular lens (or IOL, the artificial lens that replaces the cataract)

text: Pseudoexfoliation of the lens capsule is when the eye's natural lens and the supporting structures (zonules) which hold the lens in place are weakened. Modern cataract surgery and placement of the intraocular lens (or IOL, the artificial lens that replaces the cataract) are dependent on the strength of these structures. Pseudoexfoliation can vary in severity and impact on these structures. Successful cataract surgery and IOL placement can be performed safely with pseudoexfoliation, but it is an added risk factor for a safe result. Laser-assisted cataract surgery can minimize the stress of these structures and some ophthalmologists feel it results in a safer operation. This is an area of disagreement among ophthalmologists.

metadata.question: If a patient has PCO (posterior capsule opacification) in her eye after cataract surgery, should that eye be repaired with YAG laser (or posterior capsulotomy) first, or should I have cataract surgery on the fellow eye first?

text: If the PCO (when vision becomes cloudy shortly after cataract surgery) is bothering your vision significantly, have the YAG first. With YAG, or posterior capsulotomy , a laser makes an opening in the cloudy capsule holding your artificial lens and restores clear vision. It literally takes less than a minute with no restrictions afterward. You can plan to have the cataract surgery in the next days or week. There's no harm in waiting to have the YAG either.

metadata.question: Is routine pre-operative medical clearance needed before cataract surgery?

text: Routine pre-operative clearance for cataract surgery (which is usually done under local pain killer with IV sedation) is not usually necessary unless you have some serious health issues. It is required by the medical or health boards in some states.

metadata.question: Are there any tips to reduce puffiness under the eye after cataract surgery on a dense or mature lens?

links.text: Fortunately, there is cosmetic surgery called lower blepharoplasty

text: Patients often notice puffiness under their eyes after cataract surgery. The surgery does not cause the puffiness, but enhanced vision following the surgery allows you to see the aging characteristic. Fortunately, there is cosmetic surgery called lower blepharoplasty to improve the appearance of the puffiness.

metadata.question: Can I wear makeup the same day I have a YAG posterior capsulotomy ?

text: There shouldn't be a problem wearing makeup before a YAG procedure. But be to sure ask the ophthalmologist who will be doing the procedure for their specific guidance.

metadata.question: I am trying to decide whether to go with monofocal IOLs or multifocal IOLs . Is there any way to assess the odds of getting halos or star bursts which do not resolve? Is there any significant difference between brands of multifocal lenses in terms of halo or star bursts which do not resolve?

text: There is no specific test to assess the risk of halos, as every patient notices some halo/glare after the surgery. For most, this will decrease over the first three months. Some surgeons feel that certain corneal abnormalities found on measurements taken before the surgery can lead to more halo/glare after surgery but this is not absolute. Ask your surgeon about this. I would have your surgeon check this and all other pre-operative measurements to see if multifocal IOLs are a good option for you. Some doctors feel that certain multifocal lenses perform better than others. Ask your ophthalmologist what might work best for you.

metadata.question: What are some of the risks associated with not having a cataract removed? Can other damage occur as the cataract continues to get larger?

text: The main risk of not having a cataract removed is that you will be living with compromised vision from the cataract that is known to result in a higher incidence of falls as well as other problems. If your vision is not bothersome and you feel you can get around and do all activities of daily living, there is no harm in waiting. It is possible to wait too long, making the cataract operation more difficult if the cataract becomes mature or very dense.

metadata.question: What can be done if one develops a cataract after having an ICL (implantable contact lens) to cure myopia ?

links.text: Cataract removal can be scheduled electively

text: Cataract removal can be scheduled electively and should be like a regular cataract surgery. The ICL will be removed and then the cataract is removed. The newly implanted artificial lens (IOL) replaces the ICL. If additional correction is needed, glasses, contact lenses or refractive surgery can finetune the refraction.

metadata.question: What can I use for my red, itchy eyes after cataract surgery?

text: There are several reasons that eyes can be red and itchy after cataract surgery . In the first few weeks after surgery, the surgical incisions and medicated eye drops can cause irritation of the surface of the eye. Less common would be an actual allergic reaction to the eye drops. Later after surgery, the area of the incisions can still cause surface irritation, sometimes for several months. Most of these situations will improve with use of artificial tears (lubricant eye drops) to soothe the eyes. Early after surgery, while the incisions are still healing, you should use a new bottle of artificial tears or purchase preservative-free tears (which come in small plastic vials rather than a bottle) to avoid placing contaminated drops on the eye. It is best to avoid products that have vasoconstrictors to relieve redness (drops to "get the red out"). Avoid using the tears within 15 minutes before or after your medicated surgical eye drops (this could dilute the medication and reduce its effectiveness). If the lubricating drops do not help, or if the redness and itching are severe, you should contact your ophthalmologist immediately.

metadata.question: What does a rating of 4.5 for cataracts signify?

text: All ophthalmologists have different "ratings" for grading the density of the cataract . In a 5-point system, this would be a very dense cataract which would normally need removal .

metadata.question: If IOLs (or intraocular artificial lenses that replace your eye's natural lenses) are implanted as elective surgery, what is done if cataracts develop afterwards?

links.text: A cataract occurs when the eye’s natural lens becomes cloudy
“secondary cataract,” which is treated with a laser in an office setting

text: A cataract occurs when the eye's natural lens becomes cloudy and is replaced with an artificial lens. Because the lens of your eye has been removed, you can't ever develop cataracts again. You may, however develop what is called "secondary cataract," which is treated with a laser in an office setting in a minute or two.

metadata.question: I am planning for cataract surgery next spring and trying to compare the various IOLs as they would affect my balance problems from an old cerebellar stroke. Would it be useful for me to consult with a neurologist as I consider my options?

text: I don't think most neurologists would have a deep understanding of IOL designs and their effects. The best physician to speak to about this is your cataract surgeon. If your old cerebellar stroke causes problems with your vision, balance or eye movements, your surgeon might consult a neuro-ophthalmologist. The simplest thing to do to minimize potential side effects after surgery would be to choose a monofocal lens or a toric lens (if you have astigmatism ). While there is little clinical data that discusses multifocal IOLs and neurological disease, multifocals do occasionally create symptoms that in theory could worsen your existing visual function. Your cataract surgeon will be able to help you decide on the best IOL option for your specific situation.

metadata.question: What is the best IOL choice for a pilot?

links.text: traditional monofocal or toric (astigmatism correcting) lens

text: With multifocal or accommodative lenses, you have to lay off flying for 3 months per FAA guidelines. Therefore, a traditional monofocal or toric (astigmatism correcting) lens would be in your best interest.

metadata.question: What is the best treatment option for corneal edema after cataract surgery in an 72-year-old diabetic woman?

links.text: clear, dome-shaped window at the front of the eye

text: Corneal edema (swelling of the clear, dome-shaped window at the front of the eye ) after cataract surgery is quite common as the cornea can take some time to recover. Depending on the cause, there are different treatments recommended. Usually, with enough time (a few weeks on average), all that is needed are the standard post-operative drops to relieve swelling. However, if someone has unresolved inflammation/edema inside the eye , the corneal swelling can linger, and steroid drops are recommended. If the intraocular pressure is very high or very low, corneal edema can also occur. This should also be brought back into normal range with the right treatment. Sometimes, special eye drops may be needed to pull the excess fluid out of the cornea. As a last resort, a corneal transplant can be performed to replace the damaged endothelial cells responsible for the swelling.

metadata.question: What is the range of clear vision (inches from the eye) for an IOL that is set for near vision? As a photographer, I would like to have clear vision at a distance of six inches.

text: Presbyopia-correcting IOLs have different set points for near depending on the manufacturer. Talk to your ophthalmologist about which of these would provide the closest near vision given your eye health and vision needs.

metadata.question: What is the recommended time to wait after bacterial blepharitis clears before having cataract surgery ?

text: It is recommended that surgery be delayed by one week after the infection has cleared.

metadata.question: How long after cataract surgery should you wait to have upper lid blepharoplasty?

text: Generally, cataract surgeons recommend waiting 6 weeks or so before proceeding with additional surgery. This varies depending on how the surgery went and how the eye is healing, so the wait time is best determined by your surgeon(s).

metadata.question: What over-the-counter eyedrops can I use after my cataract surgery ? I used the required prescription dosage before and right after surgery.

text: If the eye is red or sore, sensitive to light, very irritated or getting blurry then you need to see your cataract surgeon for the appropriate treatment. If you are having mild symptoms of foreign body sensation, burning and/or tearing and your vision is stable and not worsening you can try any over-the-counter lubricating tear drop .

metadata.question: What are some of the risks associated with not having a cataract removed? Can other damage occur as the cataract continues to get larger?

text: The main risk of not having a cataract removed is that you will be living with compromised vision from the cataract that is known to result in a higher incidence of falls as well as other problems. If your vision is not bothersome and you feel you can get around and do all activities of daily living, there is no harm in waiting. It is possible to wait too long, making the cataract operation more difficult if the cataract becomes mature or very dense.

metadata.question: What's the difference between discission and cataract surgery?

links.text: Cataract surgery is a removal of the cloudy lens (one that has become less transparent) in the eye
artificial intraocular lens ("implant") that replaces the cataract

text: Cataract surgery is a removal of the cloudy lens (one that has become less transparent) in the eye . Modern cataract surgery usually includes leaving the original "skin" of the back surface of the eye's natural lens (called the "posterior capsule") in place in an effort to better support a plastic artificial intraocular lens ("implant") that replaces the cataract . In some cases, this capsule becomes cloudy, and a discission-creating an opening in the capsule so that light can better pass through it-can be made. This is usually accomplished with a laser and is called a "posterior capsulotomy."

metadata.question: I wear glasses to correct myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) . My glasses are no-line progressive lenses and I'm planning to have cataract surgery now at age 74. I'm thinking I'll choose either an IOL for near and intermediate vision and wear glasses for distance vision, or get an IOL for distance and use glasses for near/intermediate vision. I am likely to continue working and using a computer for another five years and I also read a lot. Which option do you think might work best?

text: It is not possible for me to tell you what intraocular lens (IOL) combination would work best for you, as this is a very personal decision. There are three basic ranges of vision: distance, intermediate and near. As it stands today, many intraocular lenses can provide excellent vision is any two of these three ranges, but none of the available intraocular lens provides excellent vision in all three ranges. There are many ways of using multifocal and monofocal lenses to deal with this problem: - Multifocal IOL in each eye for distance and near with intermediate range glasses - Multifocal IOL in each eye for distance and intermediate with near glasses - Multifocal IOL in both eyes for distance and intermediate but deliberately setting the IOL power of the non-dominant a slight bit nearsighted which makes distance vision slightly blurry if the dominant eye is closed, but does not affect distance vision when using both eyes and gives a small boost for reading when both eyes are open. - Multifocal IOL in each eye distance and intermediate, however, set such that the non-dominant eye's distance vision is slightly off focus to the nearsighted side, allowing a boost for near vision. - Monofocal IOL for distance in dominant eye and non-dominant eye set for intermediate. This is called mini-monovision. And there are more options you should discuss with your ophthalmologist.

metadata.question: You state that cataract surgery can be performed without using xylocaine (lidocaine) if one is allergic to it. What viscoelastic gel can be used in the phacoemulsification stage of the surgery that does not have lidocaine in the gel?

text: The ocular viscoeleastic device does not contain lidocaine. As far as anesthesia is concerned there are other topical drops and injectible anesthetics that can give perfectly acceptable anesthesia for cataract surgery.

metadata.question: If I have the IOL implant lenses set for near- or mid-range, will the actual range of focus be any greater for near- or mid-work than it would be if the IOL lenses are set for distance? The main distances I need are: 14" (reading), 20" (playing the pipe organ), and 36" for reading student's music while teaching.

text: The focal point will be very narrow for mid/near and distance will be blurry. If set for distance do not expect any near- or mid-distance. A multifocal lens may be a better choice for what you are seeking. Another option would be modified monovision, with one eye set for reading and the other set for intermediate - this might allow you to see at all three of your target ranges without glasses, but would require glasses correction for distance. Of course, your degree of astigmatism will affect the success of any implant lens scenario and may need correction with a toric lens or corneal procedure to achieve the best vision in your target range without glasses.

metadata.question: I was born with cataracts in both eyes. I had them removed in my teenage years and I am now 30 years old. Recently, my doctor checked and diagnosed me with posterior capsule opacity (PCO) and said I will need laser treatment. Is it really possible to have PCO so suddenly?

text: A posterior capsular opacity is a clouding of the membrane that holds the intraocular lens in place. It is the back wall of the capsule that once enclosed your eye's natural lens as well. A PCO does not come suddenly, but once the fibrosis covers a central area, it is time for a laser treatment. Everyone needs a laser treatment at some time. It is a very minor and quick procedure and may actually make your vision sharper.

metadata.question: My 8-month-old baby had cataracts removed from both eyes and wears RGP contact lenses . At what age can IOLs be implanted?

links.text: lens capsule that holds the IOL

text: The timing of placing intraocular lenses (IOL) depends on the child and the condition of the eyes. If the child is doing well with contact lenses, then sometimes that is the best initial treatment. Placement of IOLs is typically withheld until 2 to 4 years of age. However, there may be factors that may limit the ability to place an IOL. For instance, the lens capsule that holds the IOL might not be able to support it. Or there may be other diseases affecting one or both eyes. It is always best to discuss this topic with your child's managing ophthalmologist who knows your child best.

metadata.question: When you have cataract surgery and they tell you that your distance vision will be good but you will need glasses to read, will you be able to work on a computer without glasses, put on make-up without your glasses, etc.? I am kind of confused as to what my sight will be like after the surgery.

links.text: A cataract is a clouding of the focusing lens

text: The lens of the eye changes shape when you switch what you are looking at-from things that are far away to things that are very close (and at every point in between those two). A cataract is a clouding of the focusing lens . The cataract lens cannot be cleaned. It must be removed. In the old days, people had to wear very thick eyeglasses to make up for the lost focusing power of the human focusing lens. Today we replace the human lens with an artificial lens placed inside the eye called an IOL (intraocular lens) . We have a great variety of IOL options and these choices can be very confusing. The standard IOL that most insurance companies pay for has a single focus that you and your ophthalmologist agree upon. There are three basic zones of vision: far (driving), intermediate (computer) and near (reading). A standard IOL gives you one of these three zones and the other two usually require eyeglasses to achieve good vision. Other factors such as pupil size and the amount of light available can impact how well these people see for the other two zones of vision. Targeting that focus is not a perfectly accurate process, but usually the result is very close to your desired single visual goal. Most patients request their IOL focus to be for distance and understand they will need glasses for computer and near vision. Some patients ask for near vision and are willing to wear glasses to see far.

metadata.question: When you have cataract surgery and they tell you that your distance vision will be good but you will need glasses to read, will you be able to work on a computer without glasses, put on make-up without your glasses, etc.? I am kind of confused as to what my sight will be like after the surgery.

links.text: A cataract is a clouding of the focusing lens

text: is not a perfectly accurate process, but usually the result is very close to your desired single visual goal.Most patients request their IOL focus to be for distance and understand they will need glasses for computer and near vision.Some patients ask for near vision and are willing to wear glasses to see far. Some patients choose mini-monovision, such that one eye is focused for far and the other eye is focused for intermediate vision like computer distance. This requires further conversation with your ophthalmologist. More recently we have premium/multifocal IOLs that do a good job of approaching normal vision of far, intermediate and near vision, but none of them are perfect. These premium/multifocal IOLs are usually only partially covered by insurance and the patient must pay for the difference in cost between the standard IOL and the premium/multifocal IOL. I urge you to remember that no IOL guarantees perfect vision at all vision zones and under all conditions, but they do provide good to excellent visual results for most people.

metadata.question: I have cataracts , dry eyes , and astigmatism . I am confused as to whether laser or traditional cataract surgery is best for me with my dry eyes. Is there a significant difference between them in regard to post-operative vision and dry eye symptoms?

text: Some physicians prefer laser-assisted cataract surgery , and some do not. The data do not yet show a clear benefit of one over the other. More important here is that you identify your goals and if you want better uncorrected distance vision you may consider a toric IOL to correct astigmatism. If you would like to possibly be much freer from glasses and read without glasses, then a toric IOL that is also a multifocal or extended depth of focus toric lens may be able to accomplish this. Once you decide on your IOL, then laser assisted or conventional surgery are both fine and you can decide with your surgeon.

metadata.question: Any reason for the intense light sensitivity after combined cataract-glaucoma surgery with stents (small device that helps lower intraocular pressure) implanted ? It's been two months with very little improvement.

text: Light sensitivity after cataract surgery is not a rare complaint. People experience this to varying degrees because of both inflammation (swelling), and because with removal of the cataract, more light is able to enter your eye. For some, removing a cataract is like having a brown pair of sunglasses removed for the first time in many years. You should adjust some over time, but may always need sunglasses in brighter environments. Check with your ophthalmologist , but I think it is unlikely the light sensitivity has anything to do with the glaucoma stents.

metadata.question: I'm 64 and a monofocal lens is recommended due to dense cataracts and destabilizing supporting structures inside the eye. Is this a good reason not to go with multifocal or accommodative lenses? How does the multifocal lens differ from the monofocal, with respect to the supporting structures of the eye?

links.text: capsular bag (or lens capsule, the thin membrane securing the eye’s natural lens that’s left intact after surgery to hold the IOL)

text: must be placed in a secure and well-centered. If the "supporting structures" (presumably of the capsular bag) are inadequate, then a multifocal IOL may not be the best idea. Your surgeon may also be concerned about the lens becoming dislocated and moving in ensuing years. Small dislocations may create significantly more symptoms in a patient with a multifocal lens.

metadata.question: and want them removed, although my doctor said removal is not medically necessary. I am experiencing glare during night driving, blurry vision, and watery eyes. Why would I be required to wait for surgery?

links.text: The decision about timing for cataract surgery
vision (with or without glare testing) is less than 20/20

text: The decision about timing for cataract surgery is usually made based on three factors: your symptoms, your measured visual acuity (with and without glare), and the appearance of your cataract. If all three factors suggest your cataract is the primary cause for your visual difficulties, then surgery is a reasonable option to improve your vision and is generally covered by your insurance (or "medically necessary" to improve your vision). Cataracts can technically be removed when they are very early, but if the three factors to not meet certain criteria, then your insurance may not agree with the decision for surgery, and you may have to pay out-of-pocket. In your situation, the watery eyes are not a cataract symptom, but if the glare with night driving and the blurry vision are not improved with new glasses and the surgeon can document that your eyes are otherwise normal and your vision (with or without glare testing) is less than 20/20 , then cataract surgery is typically an option.

metadata.question: I had a toric Symfony lens implanted in both eyes . In one eye I still have the same astigmatism I had before the implant. The surgeon is recommending a limbal relaxing incision surgery. I am having a lot of night aberrations. He thinks this could help. Is it possible for LRI to help the night issues and is this the best approach to correct the astigmatism? I'm confused why the toric lens did not correct the astigmatism in the first place.

links.text: astigmatism (an irregularly shaped cornea that distorts vision)

text: A toric lens implant is an excellent way to correct limited amounts of the most common type of astigmatism (an irregularly shaped cornea that distorts vision) in a patient who is going to have cataract surgery . The implant lens must be positioned exactly for your astigmatism. One of the problems with any toric lens is that they might shift position in the early days after surgery, reducing the desired effect. Sometimes the cataract incision changes the astigmatism from the preoperative measurements, thus changing the effect of the toric lens you are given. LRIs (limbal relaxing incisions, incisions made between the cornea and white of the eye to correct astigmatism) were used before toric implants were perfected and are another method of treating astigmatism. LRIs can be used without entering the inside of the eye, but work best for fairly small amounts of astigmatism. LRIs don't rotate like toric lenses can do. Sometimes we use both torics and LRIs when the astigmatism is greater than the toric can correct. If you want to avoid glasses or contact lenses, the solution your eye surgeon advises is your only option without going inside your eye again. When weighing the risks and benefits, it is recommended that the surgeon not go inside the eye again and instead have the LRI.

metadata.question: I had a toric Symfony lens implanted in both eyes . In one eye I still have the same astigmatism I had before the implant. The surgeon is recommending a limbal relaxing incision surgery. I am having a lot of night aberrations. He thinks this could help. Is it possible for LRI to help the night issues and is this the best approach to correct the astigmatism? I'm confused why the toric lens did not correct the astigmatism in the first place.

links.text: astigmatism (an irregularly shaped cornea that distorts vision)

text: than the toric can correct.If you want to avoid glasses or contact lenses, the solution your eye surgeon advises is your only option without going inside your eye again.When weighing the risks and benefits, it is recommended that the surgeon not go inside the eye again and instead have the LRI. If aberrations such as halo and glare are the major issues, correction of the astigmatism may not take care of this. Some patients with multifocal or extended depth- of-focus lenses do not adapt to the optics of the lens. If this is the case, removal and replacement of the lens with a traditional monofocal lens may be the best solution. If the amount of your residual astigmatism is low, this may be the best solution for you. Please discuss with your surgeon. This question was originally answered on October 3, 2017.

metadata.question: I have minor halos from multifocal IOLs. My vision is awesome at all distances except for the halos. However, I noticed that when looking through binoculars, the halos vanish. What is it about the binoculars that causes this and are there glasses I could buy to get the same effect?

text: The halos are related to the intraocular lens (IOL) design, which has circular rings of correction. The binoculars cut off the external (non-parallel) rays of light from entering the eye. This decreases the amount of light hitting the peripheral rings of correction in the IOL. There is really no way to do this with any glasses, but you may ask your surgeon to prescribe some drops that you can use to make the pupil smaller. This may decrease but not eliminate the halos.

metadata.question: Why do I have balance/dizziness problems after cataract surgery ?

text: Depending on the type of anesthesia (painkiller) used during the operation, one can experience balance problems and dizziness after surgery, but this typically would only last a few hours. Persistent dizziness can be related to the new artificial lens that was implanted after removal of your eye's cloudy natural lens . The new artificial lens (IOL) may have a different refractive power from your previous lens and may be creating an imbalance to which you are unaccustomed. It also could be that the dizziness is completely unrelated to your surgery. You should report these symptoms to your surgeon who can investigate further. This question was originally answered on Aug. 3, 2016.

metadata.question: Why do I have to have LASIK done after I have had YAG surgery ? I had a lens for distance implanted during cataract surgery . After the YAG, my vision is still blurry, and I cannot focus. Now they want to do LASIK. Is this normal?

links.text: LASIK is an excellent way to fine tune the final result

text: Yes, if the target was not hit with your lens implant to begin with, it is typical to perform the YAG to see if it changes the vision. If not, then LASIK is an excellent way to fine tune the final result .

metadata.question: I had a toric intraocular lens implanted which corrected my astigmatism and cataract in my left eye. My vision is terrific but it looks like I'm wearing a contact lens that has a distinctive black "C" on it. It does not affect my vision, but it does not seem "normal." It almost seems like someone took a black sharpie marker and drew on the left edge of the lens. Do I need a replacement?

text: What you are describing is known as a negative dysphotopsia-an unusual reflection image. Replacement does not always fix the problem, but time usually makes it go away. Another option can be the insertion of what is called a piggyback lens which can negate the image. Talk to your surgeon about the options.

metadata.question: I just had a Panoptics lens put in a week and a half ago and I notice that I have a small crescent moon to the right. Letters have a slight glow or fuzz to them, and I have pretty severe halo effect at night and the street signs have a glow around them. Should I give it some time to change and how long? Or should I start planning on removing it and have a plain lens put in?

links.text: Panoptix lens or any multifocal lens

text: With the Panoptix lens or any multifocal lens , it is normal to have some glow as well as halos for the first six weeks or so. They generally tend to get better but do not completely go away.
