The small crescent moon may be what we call a negative dysphotopsia. This can happen with many IOLs and also should get better with time. Of course, if the visual symptoms do not improve over time, you will need to discuss alternatives including removal and replacement of the lens although this is rarely necessary.

metadata.question: My near vision has gotten worse since my cataract surgery from two weeks ago and it feels totally different than my other eye. What is the problem?

text: If you had a monofocal lens implanted (single focus lens), your area of best focus will be determined by the power chosen for this eye. If you have concerns, ask your operating surgeons what options you have in the future for better near vision if that is what you desire.

metadata.question: Why have I experienced leaky eyes since having my cataracts removed? This has caused a dryness to eyelids as well as swelling and redness around my eyes.

text: This is not typically associated with cataract surgery . I would check with your ophthalmologist to see if there is a blocked tear drainage duct that is causing the issue. This can be fixed if it is the problem.

metadata.question: Why is a multifocal lens implant not possible after vitrectomy and scleral buckle surgery (surgery that helps reattach the retina, or light sensitive tissue, to the back of the eye)? I will be having a cataract removed (surgery to replace eye's cloudy natural lens with clear artificial lens) eventually and might prefer this to monovision .

text: This can depend on a number of things. If the macula (center of the retina) was damaged by the retinal detachment or hole , multifocal lenses are not recommended as they can actually make vision worse since they decrease the amount of incoming light. Also, if there was damage to the posterior capsule of the lens during the vitrectomy , there would not be a support structure to hold this type of lens in place. It is best to ask your surgeon what he recommends and why.

metadata.question: I had cataract surgery a year ago and one of my eyes has been watering continuously almost every day for the last six months. I wake up with that eye extremely crusted at times and a thick film over it that I cannot see through until I am up and blinking it for a few minutes, then it starts watering again. Can you give me an idea of what to do?

links.text: blockage in the tear drainage duct in the eyelid

text: This may be due to a blockage in the tear drainage duct in the eyelid . I would see your eye surgeon to evaluate this. There is surgery to correct this, which is usually performed by an oculoplastic surgeon.

metadata.question: It's been three years since my cataract surgery and I have multifocal lenses. I have readers and distance vision is not sharp. What can I do for blurriness in the intermediate range (like the automobile dashboard)?

links.text: the retina in the back of the eye
refractive error should be tested and then corrected with the proper spectacles

text: Results like this are not common but do happen with all types of IOLs after cataract surgery . A comprehensive ophthalmic exam specifically looking for dry eyes , other problems with the cornea at the front of the eye, clouding behind the IOLs (known as posterior capsule opacification ), or problems with the retina in the back of the eye is recommended. If anything is found that can be treated, such as dry eyes, the treatment should be maximized. Next, the refractive error should be tested and then corrected with the proper spectacles (perhaps a low addition progressive), or even laser vision correction . If there is no eye disease and your distance vision is not acceptable even with glasses, then, in very rare cases, multifocal implants can be exchanged for monofocals, as long as the patient realizes they will not be independent of glasses.

metadata.question: Why is my vision still blurry after having cataract surgery a year ago?

text: Persistent blurry vision after cataract surgery can be due to many different things. Some causes may relate to the surgery and others, such as macular degeneration among others, are unrelated to the surgery. See your ophthalmologist for a comprehensive exam to find the cause and the appropriate treatment.

metadata.question: Several years ago, I had cataract surgery and lens replacement . What can I do now that reading has become more of a problem? I had the trifocal lens installed.

links.text: The capsule is treated with a laser (called a posterior capsulotomy)

text: If this was several years ago, I would have your surgeon look at your measurements again, do a dilated examination and see if the capsule holding the lens implant in place has clouded (may need a laser treatment). This is normal for many people after cataract surgery. The capsule is treated with a laser (called a posterior capsulotomy) that helps restore clear vision.

metadata.question: Why is saline used during cataract surgery?

links.text: There needs to be a fluid inflow during cataract surgery

text: It's not exactly saline but it is called balanced salt solution. There needs to be a fluid inflow during cataract surgery to keep the eye pressurized . A saline type solution is more compatible with the existing fluid in the eye called aqueous humor . If one were to use sterile water with no salt then it could chemically damage the cornea . It can also permanently damage the very sensitive endothelial cells of the cornea that are required to pump water out of the cornea to maintain its clarity.

metadata.question: I'm 70 years old and just recently had cataract surgery in both eyes. One eye is fine but the other has what I would call a clear mucosal film over a portion of my eye. I can wipe it away with my finger but after a few minutes it comes back. I did not have this problem prior to the surgery. Could you please tell me what is going on?

text: There is no way to tell without an exam. This could be a conjunctivitis or a blocked tear duct or something completely different. It is not a symptom of a complication of cataract surgery. Please have your surgeon re-examine your eye.

metadata.question: Why is there such a great difference in cost to patient between putting in regular lens for cataracts versus toric for astigmatism ? It seems to be same operation.

text: The issue is that the lens itself is more expensive by many times and is not reimbursed by insurance. Plus, more pre-operative measurements and calculations are needed and the follow-up after surgery can be more involved. Even the surgery itself can be different: The capsulotomy (or opening the anterior lens capsule) is lens specific. The eye has to be specifically marked for the axis correction of the toric lens, and sometimes an aberrometer (a special device that measures the way light travels through your eye) is used to make sure the lens is correctly placed. Though the operation is very similar, there are some important differences that do add cost to the procedure.

metadata.question: Why would a doctor place a contact lens on a patient's eye after cataract surgery?

text: There are several reasons an ophthalmologist might put a contact lens on a patient after cataract surgery . A person might have sustained drying of the surface of the eye (the cornea) during the operation and a "bandage" soft contact lens could make the eye more comfortable while the results of the drying heal. Some ophthalmologists place a bandage contact lens on an eye after cataract surgery, like we use a band-aid normally, to protect the small incision where the cataract surgery took place. Another reason is that a bandage contact lens can help antibiotic eye drops used after surgery remain in the eye longer and not be washed out as rapidly by tears.

metadata.question: Why would someone with an IOL (artificial intraocular lens placed in eye after cataract removal surgery) need LASIK on the same eye four weeks later?

text: No one has to have LASIK after cataract surgery , but if not all of your myopia (nearsightedness) , hyperopia (farsightedness) or astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) could be corrected with the IOL, LASIK can be used to fine tune the visual result.

metadata.question: Will cataract surgery to my right eye, which is in the beginning stage of dry AMD, have any effect on the further development of my dry AMD in that eye?

text: This is an important question that has been asked by many. There's no evidence that the surgery should affect your AMD, but it's important for your retinal specialist to be sure that you have no signs of occult neovascularization (abnormal blood vessels that grown inside the eye when one has wet AMD) prior to surgery.

metadata.question: I have a weeping left eye and normally watery eyes. I've just been diagnosed with cataracts and require surgery. Will this help with the watering eyes?

text: Watery eye (or tearing) sounds like such a simple problem, but actually there are many causes of this condition. This can be due to excessive tear production or poor tear drainage . Glare from cataracts can cause excessive tear production under certain lighting conditions but would not be expected in dimmer light. I am also concerned that you report cataracts in both eyes but only report excessive tearing in your left eye. It is possible that you have a tear drainage problem on the left. I would suggest that you speak with your ophthalmologist and ask him/her about your left eye tearing problem.

metadata.question: I had a macular hole repaired . In the year since, I have become more nearsighted in that eye (from 3 to 9). Will the cataract surgery I will need repair this and stop it from getting worse?

text: After macular hole surgery, cataract formation and worsening of cataract are common. As the cataract forms, it generally induces more nearsightedness and that can be corrected with cataract surgery.

metadata.question: Will a visual field test to check on my glaucoma be useful since I also have cataracts which affect my vision?

text: It should be useful. Part of the software in the testing machine helps minimize the effects of the cataract.

metadata.question: I use DMSO for arthritis and I need cataract surgery. Will DMSO harm the implant?

text: DMSO, a cream that is applied to the skin, helps treat arthritis and is also used to help the body absorb other medications. It will have little effect on the eye once it enters your body and no effect on cataract removal surgery or your intraocular lens (the implant) . If DMSO helps your arthritis, carry on.

metadata.question: I had a cataract removed 3 months ago and noticed the yellow/brown tint I had been seeing disappeared and whites became bright! But after having my second eye done 3 days ago, and I'm seeing the dull yellow/brown colors again. Will this resolve or is something wrong?

links.text: retina (light sensitive tissue in the back of the eye)

text: This may be temporary if your retina (light sensitive tissue in the back of the eye) is normal and without disease. If it continues, please have your surgeon re-evaluate.

metadata.question: I am 62-year-old with diabetes and was diagnosed with cataract on one eye which worsened with time. My doctor scheduled surgery for this month, but it's postponed indefinitely. My vision in the affected eye is totally blurred. Will I eventually become blind without surgery ?

text: Without treatment, the vision will become worse in the affected eye. But the cataract can still be removed in the near future when elective surgery becomes more widely available. Despite its delay, cataract surgery will correct the vision impaired by the cataract. Hang in there, help for your vision is coming.

metadata.question: Will I need a new eye examination and new lenses after cataract surgery ?

text: Yes. All measurements will usually change after your surgery and new glasses will be prescribed.

metadata.question: within the last year. Is it possible to have LASIK surgery now to reduce my dependence on glasses? I have astigmatism in both eyes.

text: Depending on the type and amount of correction and the health of your corneas, LASIK is certainly a possibility . Schedule a discussion with your surgeon who can identify the best strategy to meet your visual goals given your eye health.

metadata.question: Will a monofocal IOL improve myopia as well as a toric IOL?

links.text: Both a monofocal IOL and a toric IOL

text: Both a monofocal IOL and a toric IOL can correct myopia (nearsightedness) . However, if you have astigmatism, your vision without glasses will be better with a toric IOL than with a monofocal IOL. The toric lens can correct both myopia and astigmatism while the monofocal lens can only address the myopia.

metadata.question: I need cataract surgery . I've been told that I have astigmatism (irregularly shaped cornea) in both the back of my eyes and front of my eyes but that these offset each other which explains why my glasses only have a relatively small astigmatism adjustment of 0.25. Should I anticipate that my astigmatism will be different after IOL implants ?

text: You may need a toric lens to correct your astigmatism , since the internal astigmatism created by the lens of your eye (the cataract ) will be removed. Please discuss this with your surgeon to see what your options are.

metadata.question: My disabled aunty had cataract surgery but is refusing to let anyone put in the eye drops. Will the operation still be successful without her using them?

text: Of course, it is best that all drops are used to prevent infection and inflammation . If she is not using the drops I suggest you call her doctor ASAP and see what else can be done. If you can teach her to put her own drops in, maybe she would accept that?

metadata.question: My eyeglass prescription straightens my lazy eye. If I get cataract surgery, will it also correct my lazy eye?

links.text: prism correction (special glasses that are used to correct double vision)

text: The short answer is that if someone were to have cataract surgery , and the refractive correction they were using in their glasses is now transferred to an intraocular lens , most but not all of the time the strabismus (misaligned or "crossed" eyes) control will be about the same. There are some patients whose strabismus control worsens, and this is something to discuss with your surgeon before cataract surgery. If the question pertains to prism correction (special glasses that are used to correct double vision) , the prism cannot be transferred into the intraocular lens. So, prism glasses will be needed after cataract surgery. One thing to consider when discussing glasses use after cataract surgery with "lazy eye," is what type of lazy eye you have. If it is strabismus, then sometimes glasses will not be needed, and the strabismus control will remain the same. This is not always the case but most of the time does hold true. If by lazy eye you mean "amblyopia" , then cataract surgery may partially but not completely improve the vision. Depending on the severity of the amblyopia, cataract surgery may not improve the vision at all. For patients with moderate to severe amblyopia, they should always plan on wearing glasses after cataract surgery as the glasses protect their healthy "good" eye from injury. They will always need eye protection.

metadata.question: I am 29 and I have cataracts . I work with computers, so I've decided to get an under-corrected monofocal intraocular lens for near vision. Currently, I wear contacts to see far. I also wear these contacts while I work on my computer. After cataract surgery, will I still be able to wear contacts to see far and see my computer at the same time? In other words, will my IOLs work in tandem with my contacts lenses or would I need them taken off to see my computer?

text: These are common choices that all cataract patients need to make. You may want to consider an extended depth-of-focus lens. This will give you a continuous focus from close, intermediate (computer), and far away-perhaps requiring reading glasses for very fine print or in dim lighting. If you go with under-correction, you will need bifocals to see both near and distance at the same time. Contacts can be worn, but unless you wear multifocal contacts, which do not work for everyone, you can either see far or near, not both. Another option is monovision-one eye for distance and one eye for near or intermediate, but not all people adapt to this choice. You should discuss these options in detail with your cataract surgeon.

metadata.question: I'm farsighted and wear tri-focal glasses. I'm having a cataract removed and replaced with a lens where I won't need glasses for distance. Will my near vision be better or worse without glasses?

text: I need to see your eyeglasses prescription before any surgery to be able to answer accurately. In most cases, farsighted people will be less farsighted after cataract surgery with a lens implant and most of the time that will make the required glasses for reading and for computer less strong. That would consequently mean that your unaided reading and computer distance vision would be somewhat improved, but not perfect by any means. I suggest you discuss this with your ophthalmologist.

metadata.question: Have cataract surgery techniques improved sufficiently in the past 20 years to consider having a new intraocular lens (IOL) placed to improve eyesight, and is this even possible? I was diagnosed with and operated for a congenital cataract 20 years ago at age 3. A monofocal IOL was placed, and I now see 60 percent from my left eye. Though I am very glad to see anything from that eye at all, I lack depth perception, I can't read with the affected eye, and regularly worry about the consequences if something were to happen to my other eye. As such, I was wondering whether any significant improvement can be made in terms of eyesight through a repeat surgery.

links.text: amblyopia (when vision is one or both eyes don’t develop normally during childhood)

text: Significant improvements have been made in IOLs, but nothing that is likely to help your problem. If your childhood cataract led to a loss of vision from amblyopia (when vision is one or both eyes don't develop normally during childhood) , an intraocular lens would be unable to improve this deficit. Check with your local ophthalmologist to be sure.

metadata.question: After cataract surgery , is there any risk to dislodging the IOLs from rubbing my eyes in the morning due to excessive tearing?

text: While eye rubbing is generally discouraged right after cataract surgery, doing so will not cause an intraocular lens (IOL) to move out of position after an uncomplicated cataract surgery once the eye is well-healed. There are no hard rules here so I would recommend asking your ophthalmologist what their preference is regarding this.

metadata.question: Will a laser procedure on a secondary cataract possibly worsen macular degeneration?

text: There is little evidence to suggest that correcting a secondary cataract with laser ( posterior capsulotomy ) can make your AMD (age-related macular degeneration) worse. Your visual improvement from the laser could be limited by the AMD, but the laser is not likely to worsen the AMD.

metadata.question: Is applying sodium chloride solution only a temporary relief for cornea edema after cataract surgery or will it permanently resolve this problem?

text: Sodium chloride drops and/or ointment help remove fluid from the cornea that causes the "edema" or swelling. Topical steroids are also helpful. Corneal edema after cataract surgery usually resolves completely with time and use of the medications. Rarely, removing a very large cataract with preexisting corneal diseases such as Fuchs' dystrophy can prevent the edema from resolving. In these cases, a procedure known as endothelial keratoplasty can be performed to cure the corneal edema.

metadata.question: I'm 46. My eyes are changing so rapidly that I'm buying new glasses every year (not small tweaks). Right now I'm 20/400 walking around in 20/300 lenses from last February. I have cataracts and will have surgery in a couple of years. With my eyes not being stable, how do I choose an IOL ?

text: Once you are 20 or over, the changes that occur in your glasses are mostly likely due to changes in the lens of your eye -the very thing that has reduced your vision with cataract at this time. These changes have no bearing on the IOL choice since once the lens is removed (the cataract is the lens), the changing part of your problem will be gone. The IOL choice will be based on other things unique to your eyes and you should ask your ophthalmologist what lenses you can consider.

metadata.question: Would a cataract surgeon be able to identify a rotated IOL during an examination?

links.text: dilated wide enough to get a good look

text: Assuming you are talking about a toric lens (astigmatism-correcting IOL) being possibly rotated, the answer is yes. As long as the pupil is dilated wide enough to get a good look , this should not be a problem.

metadata.question: I have cataracts, which affect my vision, however I now see completely different colors versus subtly different hues of the same color I had seen previously. These stark differences come and go, but generally happen when I first wake up. Can I chalk this up to cataracts and old age creeping in?

links.text: Cataracts can cause changes in color perception as they progress

text: Cataracts can cause changes in color perception as they progress . The variability may be due to pupil size, lighting or dry eyes . Most likely these symptoms are due to progression of your cataracts. However, please consult with your ophthalmologist to confirm this because retina and optic nerve problems in the back of the eye can also cause these changes.

metadata.question: Can YAG treatment cause you to see huge starbursts around lights at night? I have a light-adjustable lens (LAL).

text: The YAG treatment (or posterior capsulotomy) should not have anything to do with seeing starbursts around lights at night . The light-adjustable lens should not cause much in the way of halo or starburst, either. Check with your surgeon so they can investigate what might be responsible for this symptom.
